DocumentSummary.Title: Invertebrate sample from Crassostrea virginica
DocumentSummary.Organization: McDonnell Genome Institute - Washington University School of Medicine
DocumentSummary.SampleData: <BioSample access="public" publication_date="2017-02-20T00:00:00.000" last_update="2017-03-10T09:35:17.567" submission_date="2017-02-20T12:14:03.943" id="6349363" accession="SAMN06349363"> <Ids> <Id db="BioSample" is_primary="1">SAMN06349363</Id> <Id db_label="Sample name">RU13XGHG1 #28</Id> </Ids> <Description> <Title>Invertebrate sample from Crassostrea virginica</Title> <Organism taxonomy_id="6565" taxonomy_name="Crassostrea virginica"> <OrganismName>Crassostrea virginica</OrganismName> </Organism> <Comment> <Paragraph>Whole Genome Sequencing Project. The Eastern oyster, Crassostrea virginica, provides important ecological and economical services, making it the target of restoration projects and supporting a significant fishery/aquaculture industry with landings valued at more than $100 million in 2012. While traditional breeding practices have achieved production of oyster lines with fast growth and improved disease resistance, little is known about the genetic basis of traits of commercial, biological, and ecological importance. Advanced molecular breeding techniques necessitate information regarding markers and genes associated with these traits. The goal of this research is to develop tools and resources to assist in the elucidation of the genomic basis of traits of commercial, biological, evolutionary, and ecological interest in the Eastern oyster. We propose to develop these key resources and tools by performing the sequencing, assembly, and annotation of a reference genome and transcriptome for the Eastern oyster C. virginica. Genome researchers and bioinformatics experts, in collaboration with the Eastern Oyster Genome Consortium, will use state-of-the-art sequencing and assembly strategies to achieve these aims. These reference genome and transcriptomes for the Eastern oysters will aid the research community in the discovery of candidate genes and markers associated with traits of commercial, biological, and ecological importance in oysters.</Paragraph> </Comment> </Description> <Owner> <Name url="http://genome.wustl.edu/">McDonnell Genome Institute - Washington University School of Medicine</Name> <Contacts> <Contact email="pminx@genome.wustl.edu"> <Name> <First>Patrick</First> <Last>Minx</Last> <Middle>James</Middle> </Name> </Contact> </Contacts> </Owner> <Models> <Model>Invertebrate</Model> </Models> <Package display_name="Invertebrate; version 1.0">Invertebrate.1.0</Package> <Attributes> <Attribute attribute_name="isolate" harmonized_name="isolate" display_name="isolate">RU13XGHG1-28</Attribute> <Attribute attribute_name="isolation_source" harmonized_name="isolation_source" display_name="isolation source">Rutgers Haskin Shellfish Research Laboratory inbred lines (NJ)</Attribute> <Attribute attribute_name="collection_date" harmonized_name="collection_date" display_name="collection date">2015-03-22</Attribute> <Attribute attribute_name="geo_loc_name" harmonized_name="geo_loc_name" display_name="geographic location">USA</Attribute> <Attribute attribute_name="tissue" harmonized_name="tissue" display_name="tissue">whole sample</Attribute> <Attribute attribute_name="biomaterial_provider" harmonized_name="biomaterial_provider" display_name="biomaterial provider">Rutgers and USDA ARS Shellfish Genetics Laboratory</Attribute> </Attributes> <Links> <Link type="entrez" target="bioproject" label="PRJNA376014">376014</Link> </Links> <Status status="live" when="2017-02-20T12:14:03.946"/> </BioSample>
